One of my favorite things to do in The Legend
of Zelda Ocarina of Time was to just watch
the title screen play and listen to the music.

I know that sounds silly, but there was something
about Link galloping through the twilight

of the approaching dawn that was mesmerizing
as a child?
More so, after you had completed the game.

It was like one of those odd moments where
you knew pressing start offered no new experiences,
but you still turned on the game anyways.

Leaving this on loop is an odd memory that
I have a child…

But upon booting up the game, I’d of course
seek out the edges of the world.

Link didn’t have to be anywhere, I knew
I was in the end-of-game limbo where Ganondorf
was waiting for me, but time stood still.

The internal game timeline stood still, and
you just lingered in this state of forever.

But enough reminiscing, the thing is, even
though this game was done I still set my sights
on lots of absurd challenges and rumors.

For those who have watched any of my videos
from my Six Nintendo 64 mysteries series,
you know this to be true.

And in this video we’re going to be focusing
on something pretty darn silly, but still
notable from my childhood years.
Can You Touch the Moon in Ocarina of Time?

Now that statement might seem completely reversed
in regards to what one would expect to hear
in Majora’s Mask.

Obviously, the moon is one of the greatest
threats in that game, and at the end of the

game we eventually make our way to it before
the final fight.

But back when the moon was merely something
that coasted on by in the sky, it was often
something I would find myself looking at.

Night time in Ocarina of Time was certainly
my favorite time of the day mainly because

it felt extremely free and liberating for
a child who had an earlier bed time.

Perhaps that’s why I ended up taking greater
interest in the moon over the sun, but I digress.

The reason why I wanted to go to the moon
in the first place was because of the excitement
generated around the Sky Temple.

A rumored temple that existed above Hyrule
where you would eventually collect the triforce

- which seemed like it was missing from your
inventory.

Part of that strategy, as I’m sure some
of you may remember, involved sending gossip
stones into the sky.

Obviously nothing ever came of this and the
Sky Temple ended up being a hoax, but my desire
to travel upwards in the game never subsided.

Even if you clipped out of bounds or came
to an edge of a map, you knew the world extended
far beyond where you were standing.

You couldn’t get there, and there wasn’t
anything to stand on, but you wanted to explore
it anyways.

Which takes us to the methods of trying to
get up there.

Nowadays when you’re watching speedruns,
you probably see a bunch of extremely crazy
skips and techniques.

One such technique that can be used to gain
height is called Bomb Hovering.

This allows Link to stall in midair and continually
move upwards slowly with each bomb that is
used.

The problem with this is that we’ll never
get high enough before we run out of bombs.

Basically, we’ll have Link above the horizon,
but nowhere near as tall as he needs to be
to reach the moon.

Which is a problem, because traversing vertically
at all for a scale this large is quite the
feat.
But, it certainly isn’t a dead end.

Because although the moon is sky based, it
rotates around the map.

So even though the world is flat - errr, or
at least this map is, the moon can be adjacent

to us and underneath us at different points
during the day and night cycle.

So if we clip out of bounds with Link, we
can surely just time things right and touch
the moon as we descent into darkness, right?

Well, there’s an issue with that too - because
the death barrier is going to reset our position
before we get down there.

The death barrier is actually far above where
the sun and moon are, so not even halfway
through your journey you’ll respawn up above.

So we can’t go up because we can’t gain
enough height…

And we can’t go down because we’ll be
teleported back to the map before we get there…
But what if we go horizontally?

Technically the sun and moon do a complete
rotation, so that means at one point during
their cycle they are near the horizon.

And this is where we can utilize the swordless
Link glitch.

So back on the Nintendo 64 when I first did
this, the method was a lot easier.

Not that it is difficult nowadays, but on
the older versions of the game you simply

had to have Ganondorf swat the master sword
out of your hand which cleared your B button
equipment.

You’d then simply save and quit the game,
and reload your save.

In newer versions this is fixed though, so
you have to actually utilize what is called
the Ocarina Items glitch.

This lets you play a different item as an
ocarina, which is needed because the ocarina
is banned from our fight with ganon.

As zelda.speeduns.com puts it, “When Link
has a full Bottle in his hand, you can delay

the Bottle dumping animation by jumping and
then pressing the button for the Bottle in
mid-air.

If you then quickly put away the Bottle before
you hit the ground by switching to a new item,

the game will not be able to play the Bottle
dumping animation, so it will default to the
Ocarina animation instead.”

By doing this, we can then play an item, in
this case our megaton hammer, as an Ocarina
and we can warp out of here.

This allows us to leave the fight in the newer
versions of the game and get Link swordless.

Without a sword, Link is capable of doing
a lot of strange things on Epona - like utilizing
hookshot.

If Link hookshots a wooden surface, instead
of moving to the location he shot, he’ll
actually be suspended in the air.

At this point you are free to move around
horizontally equal to the height of the head
of the hookshot.

And with this, we are free to break out of
bounds and explore to our hearts content…
This is where I left off this quest as a kid.

Exploring far out of bounds with my hookshot,
but ultimately not reaching my goal for a
multitude of reasons.

There are two huge issues with reaching the
moon this way.

The biggest issue is that the camera doesn’t
want to leave the boundaries of the stage.

Because of this, it’s hard to tell how far
out you are from the moon itself.

If you manage to align yourself to the moon,
which is a pain because it only passes by

every four minutes, you then encounter another
problem.

No matter how far you go, the moon never seems
like you can reach it.
You’re forever in front of it.
So as a kid, that was the end of it.

There was no point in trying to reach something
that couldn’t be reached - but the truth
is, what I was seeing was a lie.
Let me explain.

The biggest issue with reaching the moon is
it looks like it is a part of the sky box.

The sky box is this big rotating cube around
the world that is actually tied to the in-game
camera, and not the player itself.

This means that making Link move, regardless
of distance, will always make its so the sky
box never gets any closer.

Because Link was always in front of the sun
or moon when I did this, it would make sense

that these assets are a part of this unreachable
area…
But it’s a trick.

The reality is, the moon is actually transparent
and the reason why Link always looked like

he was in front of it was because you could
see through it - even if you did pass through
it.

You would never have been able to figure this
out on a console, unless you utilized some

sort of debug menu camera adjustment code
- but even then it would have been a nightmare.

The truth about the moon and sun is that they
are absolutely enormous and extremely far
out of bounds.

Link looks like an ant in comparison to their
size, especially when we pull the camera up
beside them to compare.

And due to how they were implemented, Link
will always show up in front of them regardless
if he’s way past them.

So after some careful planning, and measuring
my bearings on four minute intervals when

the moon when the moon would pass - which
is extremely tedious, mind you - I finally

can say I’ve touched the moon in Legend
of Zelda: Ocarina of Time.
Sure, it’s a silly concept…

But part of my childhood feels complete by
doing so.
So, how about you?

Did you have any strange goals from any video
games in your childhood?
Let me know in the comments below!
